The **[400 metres](/wiki/400_metres "400 metres") at the [Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Summer_Olympics "Summer Olympics")** has been contested since
the first edition of the [multi-sport event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-
sport event"). The men's 400 m has been present on the [Olympic athletics
programme](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the Summer
Olympics") since [1896](/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics "1896 Summer Olympics") but
nearly seventy years passed before the introduction of the women's 400 m,
which has been held continuously since the [1964
Games](/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics "1964 Summer Olympics"). It is the most
prestigious 400 m race at elite level. The competition format typically has
two qualifying rounds leading to a final race between eight athletes.

The [Olympic record](/wiki/List_of_Olympic_records_in_athletics "List of
Olympic records in athletics") for the men's race was set in 2016, and the
record for the women's race was set in 1996. [Wayde van
Niekerk](/wiki/Wayde_van_Niekerk "Wayde van Niekerk") holds the men's record
of 43.03 seconds, breaking world and Olympic records that had been held by
[Michael Johnson](/wiki/Michael_Johnson_\(sprinter\) "Michael Johnson
\(sprinter\)") since 1999 and 1996 respectively. [Marie-José
Pérec](/wiki/Marie-Jos%C3%A9_P%C3%A9rec "Marie-José Pérec") is the women's
record holder at 48.25 seconds. The [men's world
record](/wiki/Men%27s_400_metres_world_record_progression "Men's 400 metres
world record progression") has been broken several times at the Olympics: in
1912, 1932, 1960, 1968, and 2016. [Irena Szewińska](/wiki/Irena_Szewi%C5%84ska
"Irena Szewińska") is the only person to break the [women's world
record](/wiki/Women%27s_400_metres_world_record_progression "Women's 400
metres world record progression") at the competition, doing so in 1976.

Only two athletes have won the event twice: [Marie-José Pérec](/wiki/Marie-
Jos%C3%A9_P%C3%A9rec "Marie-José Pérec") became the first to defend the title
in 1996, then Michael Johnson followed with victories in 1996 and 2000. No
athlete has won more than three medals. Several medalists in the event have
also had success in the [200 metres at the
Olympics](/wiki/200_metres_at_the_Olympics "200 metres at the Olympics"):
Johnson, Perec, Szewińska and [Valerie Brisco-Hooks](/wiki/Valerie_Brisco-
Hooks "Valerie Brisco-Hooks") have all won titles at both distances. Athletes
chosen for the event almost always form part of their nation's team for the
[4×400 metres relay at the
Olympics](/wiki/4%C3%97400_metres_relay_at_the_Olympics "4×400 metres relay at
the Olympics").

The [United States](/wiki/United_States_at_the_Olympics "United States at the
Olympics") is by far the most successful nation in the event, with 21 gold
medals and 44 medals in total. The next most successful nation is [Great
Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics "Great Britain at the Olympics")
with three gold among its 13 medals. The [1908 men's 400
metres](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1908_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_400_metres
"Athletics at the 1908 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres") saw the only
[walkover](/wiki/Walkover_\(contest\) "Walkover \(contest\)") in Olympic
history, as the American finalists refused to compete in a re-run due to
British rules.[1]

## Intercalated
Games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=400_metres_at_the_Olympics&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Intercalated Games")]

The [1906 Intercalated Games](/wiki/1906_Intercalated_Games "1906 Intercalated
Games") were held in [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens") and at the time were
officially recognised as part of the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games
"Olympic Games") series, with the intention being to hold a games in Greece in
two-year intervals between the internationally-held Olympics. However, this
plan never came to fruition and the [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee") (IOC) later decided not to recognise these games as part of the
official Olympic series. Some sports historians continue to treat the results
of these games as part of the Olympic canon.[2]

At this event a men's 400 m was held and [Paul Pilgrim](/wiki/Paul_Pilgrim
"Paul Pilgrim"), a 1904 Olympic gold medalist in the 4-mile team race, won the
competition. [Wyndham Halswelle](/wiki/Wyndham_Halswelle "Wyndham Halswelle"),
later the 1908 Olympic champion in the [800 metres](/wiki/800_metres "800
metres"), was the runner-up while Australia's [Nigel
Barker](/wiki/Nigel_Barker_\(athlete\) "Nigel Barker \(athlete\)") was the
bronze medalist.[3]

## Non-canonical Olympic
events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=400_metres_at_the_Olympics&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Non-canonical Olympic events")]

In addition to the main [1900 Olympic men's 400
metres](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1900_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_400_metres
"Athletics at the 1900 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres"), a
[handicap](/wiki/Handicapping "Handicapping") competition was contested seven
days after the final. Twenty men entered, with Hungary's [Pál
Koppán](/wiki/P%C3%A1l_Kopp%C3%A1n "Pál Koppán"), Germany's [Albert
Werkmüller](/wiki/Albert_Werkm%C3%BCller "Albert Werkmüller") and [Dave
Hall](/wiki/David_Hall_\(athlete\) "David Hall \(athlete\)") of the United
States being the only non-French entrants. Koppán was the victor with a
handicap of 35 m, Werkmüller was second with a handicap of 35 m, and Frenchman
André Lemonnier took third with a 26 m handicap.[4][5]

Two [professionals-only](/wiki/Professional_sports "Professional sports")
events were also held in 1900. The [400 metres world
record](/wiki/Men%27s_400_metres_world_record_progression "Men's 400 metres
world record progression") holder [Edgar
Bredin](/w/index.php?title=Edgar_Bredin&action=edit&redlink=1 "Edgar Bredin
\(page does not exist\)") won with a time of 53.2 seconds, ahead of Legrain of
France (possibly [Paul Legrain](/wiki/Paul_Legrain "Paul Legrain")) and his
compatriot [Jules
Bouchoux](/w/index.php?title=Jules_Bouchoux&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jules
Bouchoux \(page does not exist\)"). A handicap professional race was also held
but the results have not been located.[5][6]

A handicap [440-yard dash](/wiki/440-yard_dash "440-yard dash") (402.3 m)
competition was held at [1904 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1904_Summer_Olympics
"1904 Summer Olympics") after the [1904 Olympic men's 400 m
race](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1904_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_400_metres
"Athletics at the 1904 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres"). An American, F.
Darcy, won the race with a time of 50.8 (12-yard start). [George
Underwood](/wiki/George_Underwood_\(athlete\) "George Underwood \(athlete\)"),
also of the United States, came second with no handicap and [John
Peck](/wiki/John_Peck_\(athlete\) "John Peck \(athlete\)") of Canada came
third off a six-yard headstart.[5]

These events are no longer considered part of the official Olympic history of
the 400 metres or the athletics programme in general. Consequently, medals
from these competitions have not been assigned to nations on the [all-time
medal tables](/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table "All-time Olympic Games
medal table").[5]
